Decision on Vacancy of Seat

(Announcement by Mr Speaker related to Mr Yaw Shin Leong)

Mr Speaker : Order. In a letter dated 16 February 2012, the Secretary-General of the Workers' Party informed me that Mr Yaw Shin Leong, Member of Parliament for Hougang, has been expelled from the Party with effect from 14 February 2012.

Article 46(2)(b) of the Constitution states that the seat of a Member of Parliament shall become vacant if he ceases to be a member of, or is expelled or resigns from, the political party for which he stood in the election.

Page: 1179

Article 48(a) of the Constitution states that any question as to whether a Member of Parliament has vacated his seat "shall be determined by Parliament whose decision shall be final". Article 48 also contains a proviso which permits the practice of Parliament postponing its decision "in order to allow for the taking or determination of any proceedings that may affect the decision".

It is presently unknown whether Mr Yaw is appealing against the Workers' Party decision or is otherwise challenging his expulsion.

Therefore, on the morning of 17 February 2012, that is, this morning, the Clerk of Parliament wrote a letter to Mr Yaw asking him to inform her in writing by Friday, 24 February 2012, if he intends to appeal against or challenge the expulsion. This was the practice adopted by Parliament in 1993 in the case involving Mr Chiam See Tong.

The decision on the vacancy of Mr Yaw's seat in this House will be taken when his reply is received or after the expiry of the deadline given to him to reply.

Oral Answers to Questions

Page: 1179

Abuse of Patients in Nursing Homes

1 Ms Tin Pei Ling asked the Minister for Health (a) whether there have been complaints of abuse of patients in nursing homes since June 2011; and (b) what measures have been put in place to prevent potential abuses and address any abuses discovered.

The Minister of State for Health (Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan) (for the Minister for Health) : Sir, the Ministry of Health (MOH) currently licenses a total of 65 nursing homes, providing residential care for about 9,000 patients. A total of nine complaints of alleged abuse in nursing homes were received since 1 June 2011. These complaints of abuse mainly alleged rough handling of elderly patients, particularly when the patients were being moved by nursing home staff. We have since advised the nursing homes concerned to pay more and regular attention to staff training and compliance with protocols on the handling and management of patients. We are monitoring these homes to ensure compliance with MOH's recommendations.

My Ministry takes the care provided to elderly patients in nursing homes very seriously. Should investigations reveal that staff had hurt patients due to rash acts or negligence, we will not hesitate to suspend or revoke the licence of the nursing home concerned. Serious cases may also be referred to the Police for investigations. For example, Nightingale Nursing Home has been referred to the Police and investigations are still in progress.

Nursing homes are issued two-yearly licences by the Ministry. They are inspected prior to the issuance or renewal of their licences, and on a yearly basis thereafter to ensure that all facilities and care staff comply with the Private Hospitals and Medical Clinics (PHMC) Act and Regulations, as well as the Specific Guidelines for Nursing Homes. Inspections for renewal will be more comprehensive. All nursing homes are expected to comply with these licensing terms and conditions, failing which regulatory actions may be taken against them, including suspension or revocation of their licences for serious lapses.

Page: 1180

Going forward, my Ministry is putting in place a Visitors Programme for nursing homes. The programme seeks to improve standards of care, promote patients' well-being and serves as an additional safeguard against possible abuse or lapse of care. Volunteers recruited from a diverse range of backgrounds from the community will visit the homes. They will speak with the patients and their family members about the care provided by the home and to observe the general environment. Each team of visitors will comprise both healthcare professionals and lay persons. After the visit, the visitors will provide a report on their findings to the Ministry with a copy given to the nursing home. This programme, however, does not replace the formal inspections currently conducted by MOH, which will continue. We plan to roll out the programme in April this year.

Page: 1180

Staff Strength at Home Team Agencies as Numbers of New Citizens and Foreigners Rise

2 Mrs Lina Chiam asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Home Affairs what are the plans put in place to increase the staff strength of the police force and other related agencies to cope with the tsunami of foreigners and new citizens in respect of crime enforcement and other related matters.

The Minister of State for Home Affairs (Mr Masagos Zulkifli B M M) (for the Minister for Home Affairs) : Mr Speaker, since 2008, the Ministry of Home Affairs (MHA) and Home Team departments have grown our frontline manpower by more than 2,000 officers, from 15,500 to 17,700. We will be adding another 1,400 officers this year.

The Ministry has introduced a range of measures to encourage Singaporeans to take up a career with the Home Team. Since 2010, we have taken several steps to make the career of a uniformed Junior Officer more attractive as they form the core of our frontline force. These initiatives include more academic upgrading opportunities for officers, and promoting more promising Junior Officers to the Senior Officer Corp. These measures are aimed at meeting the academic and career aspirations of our younger generation officers. Last year, we introduced a new scholarship scheme for polytechnic students, called the HOME Study Award. This enhanced scheme allows us to attract talented individuals interested to contribute to Singapore's safety and security to join the Home Team earlier.

This year, we will step up our recruitment efforts to new initiatives such as the Next-Generation Frontline Policing. We will ensure that our pay remains competitive to attract suitable and committed new recruits. We will also review our retention scheme to ensure that good officers continue to remain in the service. While MHA will continue to harness technology, maintaining safety and security will always be manpower intensive. MHA will also actively work with our community partners to keep Singapore safe and secure.

Mrs Lina Chiam (Non-Constituency Member) : Sir, I thank the Minister of State. I have two supplementary questions. First, what is the Government doing currently to prevent low level money laundering such as those in connection with our casinos? Secondly, given that a number of widely reported murder cases over the past few years that involved people who are not Singaporeans, what is the Government and the Police Force doing to assure Singaporeans that violent crime is not surging as we open our doors to others who contribute to our economy?

Page: 1181

Mr Masagos Zulkifli B M M : Mr Speaker, those are specific questions for numbers that the Member could file a Parliamentary Question (PQ) for. Generally, the increase in manpower within the Home Team is to address issues that the population faces on security and safety. As we have replied previously, we are keeping up the manpower increases with the population increase, in addition to tourist arrivals as well as hosting more events in Singapore. As an overall strategy, yes, we will have to do more if there are particular increases in particular crimes, but these are particular issues which we will handle as they come.

Page: 1181

Traffic Flow in Northern Part of Singapore to Cope with Expected Population Growth

3 Dr Lim Wee Kiak asked the Minister for Transport with the projected population increase in Yishun, Sembawang and Woodlands towns and the expected traffic disruptions and diversions due to the construction of both the North-South Expressway and the future Thomson MRT line, what additional measures is the Ministry implementing to ensure smooth traffic flow for residents in the north.

The Minister for Transport (Mr Lui Tuck Yew) : Mr Speaker, Sir, to meet the transport needs of the growing population in the north, the Land Transport Authority (LTA) has committed to constructing the new North-South Expressway (NSE) and the Thomson Line. The NSE will allow motorists travelling between the north and the city centre to save up to 30% of their travel time during peak hours. Public transport infrastructure improvements such as the Thomson Line, as well as upgrading the signaling system and adding more trains to the North-South Line will encourage more residents to switch to public transport and improve traffic flow in the north. In the nearer term, besides the widening of the Central Expressway (CTE) which was just completed last December, LTA will also be upgrading the interchange connecting the CTE, Tampines Expressway (TPE) and Seletar Expressway (SLE) to cater to traffic in the north and allow residents in Yishun town to access the CTE directly via Seletar West Link. These projects will be progressively completed within a decade.

While these projects are under construction, LTA will put in place measures to minimise impact on motorists and residents in the area. For example, prior to the commencement of construction work, LTA will carry out traffic impact assessments to determine the impact of construction to existing traffic. Necessary mitigation measures will be proposed to minimise disruption to traffic, depending on the specific situation. Where possible, lane-for-lane replacements will be provided to maintain the existing road capacity.

Dr Lim Wee Kiak (Nee Soon) : Mr Speaker, Sir, let me thank the Minister for his reply. Certainly, for residents staying in the north, particularly Yishun, Sembawang and Woodlands, the main access roadways are CTE, BKE and the trunk road of Lentor, Thomson and Sembawang Roads. The fear now is that when we start the construction work for NSE together with the Thomson Line, two of the main axes will be blocked. We are concerned and wonder if there will be more plans in the future to look at the North-South access pathway and whether more trunk routes will be opened. I am happy to hear that the Seletar West Road will be coming up, but this has been announced many years ago since I was a resident in Yishun. I just hope this project can be hastened and accelerated.

Page: 1182

Mr Lui Tuck Yew : Mr Speaker, Sir, I thank the Member for the supplementary question. I would just like to share a little more about the plans for that area since I mentioned them very briefly earlier. The intention is to expand Seletar West Link to a dual-three, from a dual-one today. There will also be a new arterial road that will link Yishun Avenue 1 to Yishun Avenue 7. This will create a new access altogether on the eastern side of Yishun town, that will connect Yishun Avenue 7 through the new arterial road down through Seletar West, and this will connect directly to the CTE, TPE or the SLE. The time frame for this is sometime in 2015.

Er Dr Lee Bee Wah (Nee Soon) : Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to thank the Minister for the confirmation of the road works, which I had already received from the LTA. I would like to ask the Minister this: besides the road works, there is a lot of feedback on the lack of bus services due to the increasing number of BTO flats being built. Could the Minister give us an update on the new bus services?

Mr Lui Tuck Yew : Sir, I had mentioned on a number of occasions previously in reply to the Member's questions that we are working with the operators with some intention to provide a certain degree of Government support for a significant increase in the capacity of the bus fleet. We will do so over the course of the next five years. When that capacity increase materialises, we will expect to see improvements not only to existing services and routes, but also the possibility of the introduction of new routes and services with this increase in capacity. May I request the Member to wait until the Ministry of Transport (MOT)'s Committee of Supply (COS) and we will have more details to share.

Mr Patrick Tay Teck Guan (Nee Soon) : Sir, just to add to the earlier questions by my colleagues. I wonder if MOT or LTA is considering Light Rail Transit (LRT) for Yishun New Town, since it is going to grow by almost 20%?

Mr Lui Tuck Yew : Mr Speaker, I thank the Member for that question. There are no such plans at this point in time.

Page: 1182

Holistic Assessment for Students at Lower Primary Levels

4 Mr Yee Jenn Jong asked the Minister for Education what is the progress on the holistic assessment approach for education at the lower primary levels that places less emphasis on semestral examinations, as recommended in the 2009 Report of the Primary Education Review and Implementation (PERI) Committee.

The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Ms Sim Ann) (for the Minister for Education) : Sir, one of the recommendations of the Primary Education Review and Implementation (PERI) Committee was to introduce more holistic assessment to support learning. Holistic assessment comprises the use of a variety of age-appropriate assessment modes. The emphasis is on skills development and to provide constructive feedback for meaningful learning.

Page: 1183

Holistic assessment is being implemented on a progressive basis, starting from Primary 1. In 2010, 16 prototype schools implemented holistic assessment in Primary 1 and Primary 2. In 2011 and 2012, another 67 and 54 schools started implementation at Primary 1 respectively. We expect the rest to start in 2013. For schools which have started earlier in the journey, efforts are now being focused on implementing holistic assessment at higher levels.

Preliminary findings from schools on holistic assessment are positive. Many teachers commented that their pupils have become more confident and are able to communicate better. Pupils also receive more feedback, have more opportunities to reflect and improve on their learning, and are developed more holistically.

Mr Yee Jenn Jong (Non-Constituency Member) : Sir, I thank the Senior Parliamentary Secretary for the answer. I would like to ask two supplementary questions. One is that when a child progresses to Primary 3, the school will face pressures, such as the Primary 4 streaming examinations and the PSLE, and it may start to switch back to being very examination-centric again. So, how can we continue to make sure that schools will support holistic assessment wholeheartedly? The second question is: how will holistic assessment eventually change the PSLE and can holistic assessment reports be used for Direct School Admission to secondary schools?

Ms Sim Ann : I thank the Member for his concerns on where we are going with holistic assessment. First, allow me to reiterate what the main purpose of holistic assessment is. Primarily, it is to place the focus on whole child development. It is also to ensure that we have ways of assessing the child for learning, instead of doing an assessment of learning. As we progress with PERI, we do help our teachers and our school leaders manage the transition. It is an important change. So, more time will be needed in order to smoothen out the process.

In doing so, we do equip our school leaders as well as our teachers with classroom resources, with learning journeys to schools that are already implementing holistic assessment, and also through workshops and seminars as well as networking, so as to ensure that we bring out the most optimal outcomes in terms of holistic assessment. There will be a place for examinations as part of the overall education journey for children. But I think, in balancing assessment as well as other modes, our main focus really is in ensuring that there is a way for us to give meaningful feedback to the child. And also in the journey for holistic assessment, we make sure that these are bite-sized and these can be handled and are helpful to both the child, the teachers as well as the parents.

Page: 1183

Retrenchments in Singapore as Economy Slows in 2012

5 Ms Ellen Lee asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Manpower (a) since the beginning of 2012, whether the Ministry has received any notification of possible retrenchments of Singaporean and non-Singaporean workers in view of the much expected slower growth this year; (b) if so, which industries are the retrenchments taking place in; (c) what are the expected numbers of Singaporeans and non-Singaporeans who will be affected; and (d) what plans does the Ministry have to help retrenched Singaporean workers.

Page: 1184

The Minister of State for Manpower (BG [NS] Tan Chuan-Jin) (for the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Manpower) : Sir, in January 2012, the Ministry of Manpower (MOM) received 22 notifications from employers on prospective retrenchments. About two-thirds of these planned retrenchments were in the services sector and one-third in manufacturing. Some 230 workers − about 60% of whom are residents − are expected to be affected. As these notifications are provided by employers on a voluntary basis, the actual numbers of retrenchments and affected workers could be higher.

Based on this feedback, there is no indication yet that the number of workers facing retrenchment has gone up sharply. The proportion of residents retrenched, based on the notifications, is also comparable to the proportion of residents employed in our workforce.

MOM is nevertheless watching the retrenchment situation closely. While our employment numbers are very strong, and unemployment is low, we do fully understand what the individuals go through when retrenched; hence, the need to do what we can to minimise retrenchments, to ensure good employment opportunities and to step in to help when it does happen. For example, during the last downturn in 2008/2009, the Government, in close collaboration with our tripartite partners, introduced several measures to help companies alleviate the situation, including ways to help them manage their workforce flexibly, instead of resorting to retrenchment. These measures help keep many Singaporeans in their jobs. If the need arises, we will once again be prepared.

Where retrenchments are inevitable, companies should carry out such exercises responsibly. This includes providing affected workers retrenchment benefits where possible, to help tide them over when they are searching for employment. Companies are strongly encouraged to notify MOM of any impending retrenchments early so that we can work closely with the Work Development Agency (WDA) and the Employment and Employability Institute (e2i) to provide employment assistance or retraining to the workers affected as well as to help facilitate their transition to new employment.

Ms Ellen Lee (Sembawang) : I thank the Minister of State for the reply. I would like to know whether MOM intends to make the notification by employers compulsory, because there will always be retrenchments taking place suddenly without any notice and leaving the most vulnerable group open to all sorts of consequences because of that.

BG [NS] Tan Chuan-Jin : As of now, there are no plans to make this compulsory. We have found over the preceding years that the way in which we interact with employers has been fairly constructive. We do acknowledge that sometimes retrenchment does happen out of the blue. What we try to do is to step in as much as possible, working with the unions, the employers and particularly with WDA, in terms of retraining, and with WDA and e2i, in terms of job placement. But this is a suggestion that we can look at, as to how we can improve the system.

Mr Yeo Guat Kwang (Ang Mo Kio) : Among the numbers being retrenched, does MOM see that nowadays, more of those from the non-rank-and-file, that is, the PMETs, are affected?

Page: 1185

BG [NS] Tan Chuan-Jin : Based on the figures that we have, the PMETs today comprise about 52% of the workforce. And based on the retrenchment numbers, the number of PMETs that have been retrenched tallied pretty much with the proportion of the workforce. So, there is no particular trend in terms of PMETs being predisposed to retrenchments.

Dr Lim Wee Kiak : Sir, I would like to ask the Minister of State this: of those who were retrenched, what was the average duration before they were re-employed? If they were re-employed, what percentage of them got back about the same pay that they had, and what percentage of them accepted a lower pay?

BG [NS] Tan Chuan-Jin : I thank the Member for his questions. We will provide the Member with the specific details. I do not have the numbers offhand. But what we try to do is to provide retraining. In terms of job placement, obviously, we are unable to place everyone.

Page: 1185

Drivers Employed by Public Transport Operators

6 Assoc Prof Dr Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim asked the Minister for Transport (a) what is the number of Singaporeans who are employed by the public transport operators as public bus drivers over the past three years; and (b) whether he can provide information on the training and orientation provided to foreign public bus drivers employed by the public transport operators.

7 Dr Lim Wee Kiak asked the Minister for Transport (a) how many foreign public bus drivers were recruited by the public transport operators over the past three years; and (b) what are the educational and language skills criteria that the public transport operators have adopted for employment of bus drivers.

The Minister of State for Transport (Mrs Josephine Teo) (for the Minister for Transport) : Mr Speaker, Sir, may I have your permission to take Question Nos 6 and 7 together?

Mr Speaker : Yes, please.

Mrs Josephine Teo : Thank you. Dr Faishal Ibrahim has asked how many Singaporeans were employed by the Public Transport Operators (PTOs) as public bus drivers over the past three years while Dr Lim Wee Kiak has asked how many foreigners have been recruited over the same time period.

As at the end of December 2011, the PTOs employed 4,405 locals, which include citizens and Permanent Residents (PRs), as bus drivers, who make up 60.5% of their driver pool. This compares to 4,620 local bus drivers or 64.4% at the end of 2010, and 4,890 or 65.8% at the end of 2009.

The PTOs have found it increasingly difficult to recruit Singaporeans as bus drivers, especially younger Singaporeans. Rising educational attainments mean higher career aspirations. PTOs have also experienced higher driver attrition, as the logistics and construction sectors have begun to offer better remuneration and work conditions, such as shorter work hours. Attrition has numbered around 1,000 each year or 14% of the driver pool.

Page: 1186

The PTOs continue to work hard to reach out to Singaporean job-seekers and were able to recruit an annual average of 280 locals over the last three years. However, to maintain service levels and cater to fleet expansion, the PTOs have had to look beyond Singapore to recruit more bus drivers from foreign countries, mainly from Malaysia and the People's Republic of China (PRC). Over the last three years, PTOs have recruited an average of 800 foreign bus drivers annually.

Dr Lim Wee Kiak has asked what educational and language skills criteria the PTOs adopt for the employment of bus drivers, and Dr Faishal Ibrahim has asked about the training and orientation provided to foreign public bus drivers employed by the PTOs.

Potential recruits who are Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents must have at least Secondary 2 education, or equivalent, and be able to speak basic English. Those from the PRC must possess at least secondary school-equivalent qualifications and be able to converse in fluent Mandarin. Preference is given to those who understand English.

In addition, all bus drivers must have either a Class 4 or Class 4A driving licence, and also fulfil the requirements set by the LTA to obtain an Omnibus Drivers' Vocational Licence (OBDVL). This requires at least a year of driving experience with a clean driving record. LTA also requires all trainees to pass a course on the relevant rules and regulations from the Road Traffic Act.

Once employed, all trainee bus drivers have to attend a mandatory training programme organised by the PTOs. This programme covers training in bus operations, customer service and safety, safe driving, emergency handling procedures and selected aspects of the public transport system, such as fare structure and bus schedules.

PTOs will additionally put their PRC drivers through English classes to improve their proficiency in basic functional and conversational English. Before they can be deployed, all trainee bus drivers undergo on-the-road training to familiarise themselves with the bus routes and the different types of buses.

The PTOs constantly review their training and refresher courses on driving safety. Bus drivers will also be sent for additional training on defensive driving and smooth driving when deemed necessary. LTA will continue to work with the operators to improve their training syllabi to raise the service levels where necessary.

Assoc Prof Dr Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim (Nee Soon) : Sir, I would like to thank the Minister of State for the reply. Public bus drivers are among the first few persons whom Singaporeans would meet daily when taking the public transport. So, I think it is important that these bus drivers are continuously immersed in the Singaporean culture, norms and also driving habits. I would like to know whether the PTOs are putting in continuous effort to ensure that these foreign bus drivers are actively engaged to be able to understand the Singaporean norms and culture, so that they can effectively engage commuters as well as do the job better to serve the Singaporean commuters and those who live in Singapore. Secondly, I would like to know if there have been active and continuous efforts put in, together with the PTOs, to see how we can employ Singaporeans, such as efforts in doing job re-design to make their schedule much better and, at the same time, improve their pay package, so that we are able to employ more Singaporeans who are able to understand the norms and culture of Singaporeans. I have received feedback that they feel more comfortable being served by them.

Page: 1187

Mrs Josephine Teo : Sir, I thank Dr Faishal Ibrahim for his questions. Perhaps I could take the second question first, and that relates to the efforts of the Public Transport Operators (PTOs) in reaching out to Singaporeans in their effort to retain a Singaporean core amongst their pool of bus drivers.

Indeed, it is the intention for us to continuously improve the work conditions of the bus drivers so that Singaporeans continue to be attracted to these jobs. I would say that, if we look at the recruitment numbers over the last three years, although it has been difficult, the recruitment efforts have not entirely been in vain. There have been Singaporeans who are willing to come forth to serve as bus drivers. This has to do with the extensive efforts by the PTOs to reach out through many different channels to get bus drivers. This includes exhibitions at various fairs that are organised by the Community Development Councils (CDCs) and also the self-help groups, and quite a lot of these take place regularly. For some time now, the PTOs have also, at the bus interchanges, set aside certain periods of the week where they conduct walk-in interviews. In other words, people who are interested to be bus drivers can walk in during those times and be assessed immediately for their suitability to be bus drivers. These efforts are on-going.

One of the other efforts which the PTOs have embarked on, which is also very commendable, is to reach out to their drivers who are about to retire and offer re-employment opportunities. These re-employments are offered on fairly good terms. The bus drivers will see their pay levels being sustained before and after re-employment, and their other benefits are also retained. This has enabled them to be able to keep these experienced bus drivers. Just to give Members a sense, for SBS Transit, two out of five of their drivers who reached retirement age, and were offered re-employment, have actually accepted it. In the case of SMRT, the figure is even better. About two in three of their bus drivers accepted re-employment upon it being offered to them. These efforts are on-going and, obviously, would have be kept up.

On Dr Faishal Ibrahim's question on the wage level, this is also an area that is being actively looked into. Minister Lui Tuck Yew had earlier shared that in the forthcoming Committee of Supply, there will be an update on what the discussions are. At that time, we will be able to reveal more details.

To the first question that Dr Faishal Ibrahim raised on norms and culture, and how foreign bus drivers can be given more opportunities to interact with Singaporeans and to be able to relate to them in the way that they are used to, perhaps, I could share with Members that, for SBS Transit, for example, when the bus drivers are recruited, they go through a training programme. For non-Singaporeans who are perhaps assumed to be less familiar with our culture and norms, the training period is actually quite significantly longer. In the case of PRC drivers at SBS Transit, for example, the training period is about seven weeks, compared to four weeks for the Singaporean drivers that they recruit. So, it is considerably longer. One of the modules, for example, that is covered in this extended training period is English Language.

But, of course, as we know, language is not something that we learn in the classroom over the course of several days and are able to master, because there are different ways in which the language is spoken in the community, and these different ways in which they are spoken take time to get used to. So this is a continuous effort, and the PTOs are very aware of it. If there is specific feedback from members of the public regarding specific drivers, PTOs will also look into them and make available refresher courses, not just for language but also on city driving and other aspects.

I would just want to find out the reason for this very high attrition rate and whether anything is being done to tackle it.

Mrs Josephine Teo : Mr Speaker, Sir, Dr Lim has asked about the wages of the bus drivers. This is something that is for the PTOs to address. I can convey the Member's information request to them and they can respond to him if appropriate.

On the question of attrition, perhaps I should make a clarification. What I said was that, each year, between the two public bus operators, about 1,000 of the bus drivers leave service, and this translates into an attrition rate of 14%. So it is 1,000 and 14%. In terms of the recruitment, it is 280 locals on average over the last three years, and 800 foreign bus drivers averaged annually over the last three years. That is just to put those numbers into context. Dr Lim has also asked: why this high turnover rate? If we look at the turnover relative to other service sectors that also experience heavy competition for labour, 14% is, I would say, not so out of the ordinary, although it is the number that we still want to pay attention to. The main reason, really, has been that in a very tight labour market, many job opportunities have opened up for the bus drivers. Given a choice, the bus drivers may leave for the advantages the other job offer. These may not always pay higher salaries, but in terms of the work conditions, which may be quite attractive to some of the drivers.

Two things that have emerged among the reasons why the public bus drivers choose to go and work in other sectors are, firstly, in terms of the work hours they find that it is better for family life. Secondly, also in many other areas of work, they may not necessarily have to face the public, and have to deal not just with the technical aspects of driving but also the customer service. So these are two factors that have emerged that public bus drivers have concern about.

On the Member's third question on whether in the licensing for the PTOs, there is a requirement for them to hire a minimum number of Singaporeans. Actually, the PTOs, like all other commercial enterprises operating in Singapore, are subject to the same foreign worker policies that the Ministry of Manpower administers. What it means is that the dependency ratio ceiling, commonly referred to the foreign worker quota, applies to the PTOs as well. What it means is that there is a certain core of Singaporean drivers that they must always keep.

3G Broadband Coverage on MRT Trains

8 Mr Gerald Giam Yean Song asked the Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts (a) how does IDA track the telcos' 3G mobile broadband coverage on MRT trains to ensure that they meet the required quality of service (QoS) standards; (b) what were the actual measured 3G mobile broadband service levels on MRT trains in the latest month with available measured data; and (c) whether IDA has plans to publish the actual measured service levels on a regular basis.

The Senior Minister of State for Information, Communications and the Arts (Ms Grace Fu Hai Yien) (for the Minister for Information, Communications and the Arts) : Mr Speaker, Sir, IDA recently enhanced the Quality of Service (QoS) framework for 3G mobile telephone services, to ensure better mobile coverage for consumers. For existing MRT tunnels, the QoS standard has been enhanced from an average of 95% service coverage across all existing roads and tunnels to a specific 95% service coverage within each MRT tunnel. New MRT tunnels to be built also face a more stringent service coverage standard, such that the service coverage in each of the new tunnels must be more than 99%. These revised standards for MRT tunnels will take place from 1 April 2012 onwards.

Page: 1190

Mobile telephone operators are required to measure their performance and submit quarterly reports to IDA. IDA also conducts independent audit and measurements of the mobile operators' QoS performances regularly. So far, operators have met the existing QoS standard of an average of more than 95% service coverage across all tested roads and tunnels.

Currently, IDA publishes the operators' performance for outdoor coverage on an annual basis. Going forward, IDA intends to publish the operators' performance for MRT tunnel coverage as well.

Separately, IDA has not set QoS standards for broadband speeds, whether it is for fixed or mobile broadband services. This is because broadband speeds are affected by a myriad of factors which may be beyond the operators' control. Mobile broadband services are further affected by factors, such as the type of handsets used and the number of concurrent users at that location at the time of usage. IDA is currently studying the feasibility of imposing a QoS framework for mobile broadband services. In the interim, IDA will require broadband service providers to publish the typical download speeds likely to be experienced by end users from 1 April 2012 onwards.

So what accounts for this poorer level of service on the North-South-East-West Lines?

My second question is, for the 95% or the soon to be 99% in April, does this number only cover roads, or does it also cover the MRT lines that are above ground which may not necessarily be along the road? And, lastly, does the Government consider 3G connectivity on MRT trains to be just a nice to have for recreational Internet surfing or is it an important tool for business either now or in the future?

Ms Grace Fu Hai Yien : Mr Speaker, I thank the Member for the supplementary questions. As far as the reports that we are receiving at IDA, the service level that we have received so far has been good. Right now, under our regulatory framework, the service providers are supposed to capture the signals at various points of the tunnels, including platforms, including above-ground tracks, and they have moved in two directions so as to have a more reflective measurements of the performance of the system. And our data so far showed that the data has actually been quite satisfactory. So I am not sure how the Member has arrived at that conclusion. For the second question about the roads, whether we are just measuring MRT tunnels or include MRT tracks above ground, as I mentioned earlier, our operators are required to capture the entire train service on the move in both directions. So that would include above-ground tracks as well. We view the Internet and the communications facilities as an important part of Singapore's competitiveness in attracting business, and that is the reason that we have invested heavily to improve the service provision and also improve the infrastructure and get ourselves ready for the future.

Implementation of National Mental Health Blueprint

9 Ms Tin Pei Ling asked the Minister for Health (a) if he would provide an update on the implementation of the National Mental Health Blueprint that was proposed in 2007; (b) how are Singaporeans with mental health conditions (but not institutionalised) currently supported in the community; and (c) whether there are plans to further strengthen the network and structure of support in the community for Singaporeans with mental health conditions.

Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan (for the Minister for Health) : The National Mental Health Blueprint (NMHBP) was developed in 2006. To date, about $178 million has been invested, and results have been encouraging.

One of the key thrusts of the Blueprint was to increase public awareness and education about mental health. The Health Promotion Board (HPB) has organised programmes in schools, workplaces and community settings to increase awareness of mental health issues and facilitate early detection and treatment. More than 40 initiatives and activities were organised last year, reaching out to some 170,000 students and members of the public.

Another key aspect of the Blueprint was to develop integrated mental health services. Hospital-based teams have been set up to provide integrated mental healthcare and physical intervention for patients with health problems such as those with stroke, diabetes or trauma who are also at risk of developing mental health problems. We have set up multi-disciplinary community mental health teams, comprising doctors, nurses and allied health professionals, to provide clinical services to patients in the community as well as urgent intervention in the case of crisis situations. We have also introduced programmes to train community health providers such as family physicians and counsellors to enable them to better manage mental health conditions. Going forward, we plan to scale up the successful programmes nationally.

Page: 1192

With regard to current community support for people with mental illnesses, the Institute of Mental Health (IMH) runs three off-site specialist outpatient clinics across Singapore and continues to develop links with the community and grassroots agencies to ensure that discharged patients have adequate family and social support. Currently, there are two Psychiatric Rehabilitation Homes, one Psychiatric Sheltered Home and eight Psychiatric Day Care Centres. These facilities provide transitional care and rehabilitation services for patients to assist their reintegration into the community.

Although we have made significant progress, there is much more that we can do to improve community support for persons with mental illness. We will be developing more medical and allied health teams in the community to further strengthen the delivery of mental healthcare in community settings. We will also be developing Intermediate and Long-Term Care services in the community for patients with mental illness. We will be sharing further details on our plans in the upcoming Committee of Supply (COS).

Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan : Firstly, I want to thank the Member for her very useful suggestions and views. Indeed, these are areas that we are looking to strengthen with respect to provision of care and support for patients that are suffering from mental illnesses that may have been discharged into the community. As regards the services, besides the three decentralised specialist clinics that IMH operates, basically, we have various programmes that are targeted to assist patients who may have been discharged into the community. They are assessed to be stable, so they are discharged into the community, and this is in line with our community-based psychiatric care model. Some of the other services available would be, for instance, adult community mental health team which manages patients with mental illness that have been discharged in their home through psycho-social rehabilitation and crisis intervention.

So once they are discharged, they are referred to GPs under this programme who will follow up with the patients. And there are a variety of other programmes.

As regards her second question of what we can do for early detection and hence treatment of people who may have mental issues, including dementia, let me say, firstly, that our Ministry recognises that we need to develop a system of comprehensive management and safe discharge of patients recovering within the community. Onsite supervision of Sizeable Projects

10 Mrs Lina Chiam asked the Minister for the Environment and Water Resources for sizeable projects undertaken by his Ministry whether there are specifications given to contractors on the frequency of onsite supervision which the contractors must conduct and, if so, what is the frequency specified.

The Senior Minister of State for the Environment and Water Resources (Ms Grace Fu Hai Yien) (for the Minister for the Environment and Water Resources) : Mr Speaker, Sir, all construction works in Singapore, whether it is undertaken by the MEWR family, other public agencies, or the private sector, must comply with environmental standards prescribed by the National Environment Agency (NEA) and PUB, the National Water Agency.

NEA regulates the maximum permissible noise levels for construction work. NEA also requires contractors to conduct weekly checks for mosquito breeding within their construction sites and to put in place preventive measures. Contractors have to comply with PUB's requirements to implement earth control measures (ECMs) by engaging a Qualified Erosion Control Professional (QECP), to design and supervise ECMs throughout the construction period, to prevent silt from construction sites from being washed into our waterways and waterbodies during heavy rains. NEA and PUB leverage technology to complement physical checks by NEA and PUB officers on the sites. For example, all construction sites are required to install noise meters, while online CCTV cameras and sensors to detect silty water are installed at the drainage outlets of major construction sites to detect the quality of discharge.

Page: 1195

All construction sites with contract sums of above $10 million are required to employ an Environmental Control Officer (ECO). The ECO will be required to develop a Site Environmental Control Programme for the construction site to address potential environmental issues such as noise, air and dust pollution; earth littering and siltation of drains; breeding of mosquitoes and rodents; proper waste management and provision of toilet facilities. The ECO is expected to carry out site inspections to ensure measures drawn up under the Site Environmental Control Programme are adhered to. He is expected to be on site for at least 15 hours a week, while for projects with contract sums above $50 million, he will have to be on site for 40 hours a week. If any irregularities are observed during his inspections, he is required to identify and report these conditions/situations to the contractor, together with recommendations on remedial measures to be taken to prevent recurrence.

I wish to assure Mrs Chiam that the Ministry, together with NEA and PUB, takes a serious view on environmental and water pollution, and will continue to work with our stakeholders and partners to ensure a clean environment for Singapore. The public can contact PUB and NEA through their respective 24-hour hotlines to provide feedback on these issues.

Mrs Lina Chiam : Sir, I thank Ms Grace Fu for answering the question. I would just like to ask if there are any penalties for contractors if they default in their supervision.

Ms Grace Fu Hai Yien : I thank the Member for that question. There are penalties under various regimes, whether they are for mosquito breeding, noise, siltation, and so on. Various penalty regimes are applied on contractors.

12 Ms Ellen Lee asked the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports whether there have been efforts made to persuade private sector employers to give their employees Parent Care Leave and what is the profile of employers who have agreed to grant their employees such leave.

The Minister of State for Community Development, Youth and Sports (Mdm Halimah Yacob) (for the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports) : Mr Speaker, Sir, with the rapidly ageing population as well as decreasing family sizes, we recognise some families need more support to cope with the demands of care giving. At the workplace, employers are encouraged to adopt family-friendly practices and flexible work arrangements. Incentives, such as MOM's Work-Life Works! (WoW!) Fund, have also been put in place. We are also aware that some collective agreements have begun to provide for family friendly benefits.

Ms Ellen Lee asked what efforts are being made to persuade private sector employers to give their employees Parent Care Leave and what are their profiles. According to MOM's Conditions of Employment Survey in 2010, the proportion of private sector establishments that offered parent care or parental sick leave has almost doubled from 5.9% in 2008 to 10.6% in 2010. Not surprisingly, this was more common among larger establishments with 200 and more employees. Industries such as community, social and personal services, hotels and restaurants as well as information and communications services appeared to be better able to offer such leave. Earlier this year, the Civil Service introduced two days of annual Parent Care Leave.

These are positive developments in the private and public sectors. I would like to encourage more employers to adopt similar practices for the benefit of their employees. Where the employers are unionised, they could negotiate with their unions to consider including family-friendly benefits in their collective agreements. Eldercare leave is just one of many options to support families in care giving. We will also continue to encourage family-friendly work practices, taking into consideration our demographic trends as well as the challenges and considerations of employers.

Incidence of Cardiac Events During and After Individual Physical Proficiency Test (IPPT)

13 Dr Lim Wee Kiak asked the Minister for Defence (a) what is the incidence rate of cardiac events during and after Individual Physical Proficiency Tests (IPPTs) over the past five years; (b) whether there are any plans to review the IPPT criteria; and (c) what additional medical screening procedures are in place to minimise such cardiac events.

The Minister for Defence (Dr Ng Eng Hen) : Mr Speaker, Sir, the Individual Physical Proficiency Test (IPPTs) remains an efficient and effective tool for testing the fitness of large groups of servicemen. Appropriate standards are set for different categories of servicemen according to gender, age and medical status. These standards are comparable to those used by armed forces in other countries such as the United States and United Kingdom.

About 116,000 SAF personnel take the IPPT annually. Over the past five years from 2007 to 2012, two cases of sudden cardiac deaths occurred during or soon after IPPT. This works out to an incidence rate of 0.345 cardiac fatalities per 100,000 persons, or 3.5 per million. This is comparable or equivalent to the age comparable population rate. This is low rate but despite this low occurrence rate, the SAF takes a serious view of any cardiac death or for that matter, any training-related injury or fatality.

Comprehensive medical screening is conducted for all National Servicemen during their entire NS period or over his career for regulars. The screening guidelines for heart-related conditions are developed by a panel comprising leading senior cardiologists from the public sector and senior SAF doctors. These guidelines are regularly reviewed taking into account the latest medical evidence and clinical best practices – the most recent, in May 2011. These guidelines are in line with and, in some instances, exceed existing national and international standards.

All pre-enlistees undergo a medical review by the SAF Medical Officer to detect electrical or structural heart abnormalities which includes routinely, a chest X-ray and resting electrocardiogram or ECG. Where abnormalities have been detected, they are referred for further evaluation, which may include treadmill ECG and heart ultrasound, or referral to a cardiologist.

SAF servicemen also undergo medical screening before any major training activities, such as overseas exercises to determine if they are fit for that activity. Should a serviceman develop symptoms or become unwell, he is to consult a Medical Officer at any time, irrespective of whether he is due for a scheduled medical review.

Page: 1198

All servicemen, Regulars and NSmen aged 35 years and above, undergo health screening annually before they are allowed to take the IPPT. This health screening comprises a medical examination by a medical officer, a resting ECG and blood tests for cholesterol and sugar levels. When required, servicemen would be referred for further tests including treadmill ECG, stress heart ultrasound and other specialised investigations, such as CT calcium scoring and nuclear medicine cardiac scans. They can only take part in IPPT if they have successfully completed the health screening process. The SAF reviews its health screening and training processes on a regular basis to ensure that we adhere to the highest standards of safety.

Our CET system has been enhanced in recent years to better support both company-sponsored and self-initiated training. Mr Tay also asked about mechanisms to protect the interests of freelancers, especially with regard to fees owed to them. Freelancers can seek redress for late payment of service fees or other contractual disputes through the Small Claims Tribunal or the Subordinate Courts, depending on the claim amount and the nature of dispute.

In addition to the existing official channels, there are other complementary efforts to help freelancers. For example, MDA has been working with the industry group, the Association of Independent Producers (Singapore) or AIPRO, to establish a code of industry best practices to guide relations between companies and freelancers. The key areas included in the code are: terms of payment, contractual terms, insurance coverage and dispute mediation. The introduction of the code is targeted for end 2012, and this should prove to be helpful.

But in instances where employers attempt to disguise their employees as "freelancers", let me emphasise that they would not be absolved of their responsibilities under the law, including the Employment Act and CPF Act. Also, their employees would have recourse to the Labour Court. When such cases come to the attention of MOM, we will not hesitate to investigate and take the companies to task if they are guilty of breaching employment or other relevant laws. Therefore, MOM urges individuals who are unsure of their employment status to come forward to MOM for advice and assistance.
