Online Piracy Transactions

(Originating countries and economic impact of such transactions)

3 Mr Chen Show Mao asked the Minister for Law what is (i) the extent of online piracy transactions in Singapore; (ii) the extent to which such transactions are conducted at websites based outside of Singapore; and (iii) the economic effect of such transactions.

Mr K Shanmugam : Online copyright infringement is a transnational issue, as Internet users are able to visit, view and obtain content from websites which are hosted overseas and which thus fall outside Singapore's legal jurisdiction. It is a challenge for many countries, including Singapore, to assess the extent of copyright infringement and its economic impact.

Studies offer different conclusions on the impact of online copyright infringement on the creative industries. Some have argued that the sales of books, music and movies have declined due to availability of infringing copies on the Internet. Others have found that sales may actually have been boosted due to increased awareness of the products amongst consumers due to their availability over the Internet.

Some countries have proposed, and in some cases introduced, measures to address online copyright infringement. These include the blocking of sites and the Graduated Response (or "Three Strikes") system. However, there is at this state no clear consensus on a particular set of measures being effective. Concerns have also been raised that too sweeping an approach may hamper the legitimate use of the Internet.

MinLaw will continue to monitor the efficacy of such measures. We would need to ensure that our intellectual property regime remains robust enough to deal with the changing digital environment, whilst preserving the legitimate use of the Internet by the public.

Page: 1234

Regulation, Standards and Development for Aged Care Workers

4 Mr Chen Show Mao asked the Minister for Health whether there are regulations and standards that apply to, and approved training and development programmes for, care workers in aged care for (i) nursing homes; (ii) senior activity centers; (iii) day social and rehabilitative care centers; (iv) home-based healthcare services; and (v) home-based social care services.

Mr Gan Kim Yong : There are guidelines and regulations as well as training and development programmes in place for registered healthcare professionals in the aged care sector.

In terms of regulations, doctors and nurses who work in nursing homes or provide community-based or home-based healthcare services must go through the requisite training and meet the licensing requirements as set out under the Medical Registration Act or the Nurses and Midwives Act, as the case may be. Only graduates of training programmes which are accepted by the various professional licensing Boards, such as the Singapore Medical Council and Singapore Nursing Board, qualify to practise in Singapore. Foreign healthcare professionals also need to possess the requisite qualifications and training set by the respective professional licensing Boards in order to practise here. There are also guidelines on standards and manpower qualifications for the social care sector.

In addition, there are ongoing efforts to upgrade the skills of aged care staff. Support staff, such as healthcare assistants or therapy aides, can undergo training and development through Singapore Workforce Development Agency's (WDA) Workforce Skills Qualifications (WSQ) Course in Healthcare Support or Therapy Services. Aged care staff can also attend courses, such as the ITE Skills Certificate in Healthcare (Home Care), qualifications in Senior Services via the WSQ training framework, and courses offered by the Social Service Training Institute (SSTI).

Since 2002, MOH has invested in building up the capability of intermediate and long-term care (ILTC) staff through the Healthcare Manpower Development Programme (HMDP-ILTC), which is aimed at helping the sector build up advanced skills in elderly and continuing care. Over the last five years, we have awarded 350 people the HMDP-ILTC Fellowship. In addition, the Agency for Integrated Care (AIC) has established a Learning Institute (LI) in 2010 to facilitate capability building in the sector by organising skills training for ILTC staff. To date, the AIC LI has facilitated 130 runs of courses providing more than 5,000 training places.

Beyond upgrading the skills of aged care staff, there are also initiatives to improve the quality of the aged care sector. Since August 2010, AIC has collaborated with three community hospitals and 20 nursing homes on quality improvement initiatives in areas such as continence care, multi-dose medication and hand hygiene to ensure better quality of care for the patients and residents.

Nevertheless, there is still room to further improve care standards. The Government agencies will continue to study ways to enhance our guidelines and regulatory standards as well as to work with care providers to better train and develop staff.

Licences for Nursing Homes and Lapses in Patient Care at Licensed Nursing Homes

5 Mr Chen Show Mao asked the Minister for Health in each of the last three years (a) how many applications were submitted for new licences of nursing homes for the aged sick and the elderly and, of these, how many licences were granted; and (b) how many nursing homes did not receive renewals of their licences following regular audits by the Ministry.

6 Mr Chen Show Mao asked the Minister for Health in each of the last three years (a) how many cases of serious lapses in patient care at licensed nursing homes were reported; and (b) what actions were taken by the Ministry in such cases.

Mr Gan Kim Yong : The Ministry of Health (MOH) has licensed a total of 65 nursing homes, providing care for about 9,000 patients. MOH received and approved six, three and five applications for new licences in 2009, 2010 and 2011 respectively.

In the last three years, one nursing home was not granted a renewal of licence, as it failed to comply with a Ministry directive to maintain the premises in a good state of repair and hygienic condition at all times. It was closed on 31 March 2010, after arrangements were made to re-house the patients to other homes.

In the period 2009-2011, there were four cases of serious lapses resulting in death of serious injury in nursing homes. In all cases, my Ministry launched in-depth investigations to determine if there were inappropriate practices or non-compliance with the Ministry's licensing requirements and took action accordingly. In one of the cases, the nursing home had failed to send a patient promptly to the hospital for treatment. This nursing home had been given a composition of the offence for $2,000. Another home was suspended from taking in new patients. Investigations are ongoing for the remaining two cases.

Nursing homes are issued two-yearly licences by my Ministry. They are inspected prior to the issuance or renewal of their licences, and on a yearly basis thereafter to ensure that all facilities and care staff comply with the Private Hospitals and Medical Clinics (PHMC) Act and Regulations as well as the Specific Guidelines for Nursing Homes. All nursing homes are expected to comply with these licensing terms and conditions, failing which regulatory actions may be taken against them, including suspension or revocation of their licences for serious lapses.

Coverage of MediShield Insurance

10 Mr Gerald Giam Yean Song asked the Minister for Health (a) what is the percentage of Singaporeans currently not covered by MediShield insurance; (b) of these, what proportion comes from (i) the young aged below 21 years; (ii) non-working adults or spouses; (iii) the elderly aged above 75 years; and (iv) people who are excluded due to pre-existing illnesses or congenital anomalies; and (c) what is being done to increase the proportion of insured Singaporeans.

Mr Gan Kim Yong : As of end-2011, over 92% of Singaporeans (about 3.5 million) were covered under MediShield.

Coverage for those below age 21 stood at 94% as at end-2011, up from 55% as at end-2007. This was due to the introduction of a new auto-cover point for newborns in 2007 and a one-time auto-cover exercise for all youths below age 21.

Page: 1239

Of the working-age population aged 21 to 65, 95% are insured under MediShield, up from 89% as at end-2007. The remaining 5% may not be covered by MediShield due to a range of reasons. These would include those who have not held formal employment yet and hence have not been reached by the CPF Board, or opted out of MediShield because they had separately purchased private comprehensive insurance, or already enjoy some employer medical benefits.

Coverage of the elderly aged between 76 to 85 18 years is about two-thirds (65%) of the population.

Those with pre-existing or congenital conditions but are otherwise in good health are able to apply for MediShield coverage for medical treatment not related to their conditions. So far, fewer than 1% of the total resident population was not able to obtain MediShield cover due to pre-existing conditions.

Over the years, CPF Board has intensified its efforts to reach out to the uninsured. Auto-cover points which include (i) at birth; (ii) when one starts work; (iii) at the point of marriage registration help to raise the coverage of MediShield. There are also regular outreach and publicity efforts to encourage Singaporeans to take up MediShield.

For those who are uninsured, heavy Government subsidies and Medisave will continue to help to offset their bills. Those who face difficulty affording their medical bills can also approach the medical social workers at the public healthcare institutions for financial assistance such as Medifund. The Government will also top up the Medisave accounts of Singaporeans from time to time when there is a Budget surplus.

18 The maximum coverage age of MediShield is 85 years old.

Public Assistance Scheme and Caseload at Community Development Councils

11 Mr Muhamad Faisal Bin Abdul Manap asked the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports in respect of the Public Assistance Scheme for each of the years from 2006 to 2011 (a) what was the number of applications to the Scheme; (b) what was the percentage of applications that were rejected; (c) what were the reasons for rejection and their percentages; and (d) what kinds of follow-up checks or assistance were provided to rejected applicants.

13 Mr Muhamad Faisal Bin Abdul Manap asked the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports for each of the years from 2007 to 2011 (a) what was the average caseload of Community Development Council (CDC) ComCare consultants in terms of active ongoing cases per month; (b) what was the average number of new cases assigned to CDC ComCare consultants per month; (c) what was the average number of investigations per consultant conducted by CDC ComCare consultants; (d) what was the average number of CDC ComCare consultants per supervisor; and (e) what was the percentage of CDC ComCare consultants who are professionally trained social workers.

Mr Chan Chun Sing : The Public Assistance (PA) scheme provides Singapore citizens, who due to age, illness, disability or family circumstances, are unable to work and have little means of support. Most PA recipients remain on the scheme for the long term. Between 2007 and 2011, the number of new applications, approvals and rejections are as shown below:

Page: 1240

Among the rejected applications, 37% was due to the applicants having income, savings or other forms of financial support. Eighteen percent could not be processed because the applicants did not provide the necessary information for proper assessment or could not be contacted. The remainder were rejected due to other reasons, including clients withdrawing their applications.

Applicants who are not eligible for the Public Assistance scheme but still need help may be assisted under other ComCare schemes for the short to medium terms. Some may also receive help through the CDCs' local schemes or referred to help agencies such as Family Service Centres for other forms of assistance.

For each of the years between 2007 and 2011, active ComCare cases 19 handled by a CDC officer numbered between 60 and 84. The average was 70. Similarly, for each of the years between 2007 and 2011, new applications per CDC officer numbered between 13 and 26 per month, with an average of 20 per month.

A supervisor will supervise about six social assistance officers. Each case would involve some form of investigation. However, the bulk of a CDC officer's work in administering ComCare cases does not require professional social work training. About 6% of the investigative officers have social work degree. Clients who need social work intervention will be referred to the Family Services Centres.

19 Active cases defined as households that were receiving assistance as at 31 December of the year specified. CDC officers refer only to officers who handle cases on the Work Support Programme, ComCare Transitions scheme and Public Assistance scheme.

Caseload at Family Service Centres

12 Mr Muhamad Faisal Bin Abdul Manap asked the Acting Minister for Community Development, Youth and Sports for each of the years from 2007 to 2011 (a) what was the average caseload of Family Service Centre (FSC) social workers in terms of active ongoing cases per month; (b) what was the average number of new cases per social worker assigned to FSC social workers per month; (c) what was the average number of investigations per social worker conducted by FSC social workers; and (d) what was the average number of FSC social workers per supervisor.

Page: 1241

Mr Chan Chun Sing : The number of monthly active cases per FSC social worker was 49 in 2007 and 43 in 2011, while the average number of monthly new cases per social worker was four in 2007 and three in 2011.

The casework and counselling sessions conducted by each social worker per month will vary depending on the nature and complexity of the cases. Each FSC supervisor oversees about three to four social workers.

As announced during the FSC Seminar on 9 February 2012, MCYS will provide FSCs with more resources to further reduce the caseload of FSC social workers by 20%, to enable them to invest more time in helping vulnerable families with more complex needs.
